in times of volatility, spreads will widen, but fills will happen
the only reason such quote would fail simulation is if after you received it and before it confirmed onchain, someone else executed on that inventory. which happens very, very rarely

the way private market maker quotes work is as follows. you ask for a quote, they send you a quote at a fixed price (so min received = what you're quoted). if there's no last look on the maker side, your quote arrives with the call data you can submit and here you go, no unexpected slippage and a guaranteed fill

it depends on the machanics (whether they have last look on their end or not), but most trading via private market makers doesn't have last look. over 90% of the quotes we issue are executed without last look

I like that you talked about under hiring, it's something this space kind of sucks at. Even when there is cash on hand, there's this weird obsession generally driven by lacking leadership or management experience in general, that forces everyone to stay in a perpetual "crunch" with "as lean as possible" mentality. It's how you chew through good workers and spit out a bad experience. Alternatively, there's a flip side where they stack teams with too many inexperienced people by picking them up like stray animals, where you won't get much of anything from it. 
BD has always been around, but they largely fell into the bucket of people lacking experience on doing business trying to deal with other people who are equally incapable of doing business because it's all very easy when times are good and crypto is pumping but these projects should have been run as businesses from day 1. The only reason they weren't is due to mostly unprecedented access to capital by people that have never had access to it.
